review.title: Bayesian Optimisation for Safe Navigation under Localisation Uncertainty
review.abstract: In outdoor environments, mobile robots are required to navigate through terrain with varying characteristics, some of which might significantly affect the integrity of the platform. Ideally, the robot should be able to identify areas that are safe for navigation based on its own percepts about the environment while avoiding damage to itself. Bayesian optimisation (BO) has been successfully applied to the task of learning a model of terrain traversability while guiding the robot through more traversable areas. An issue, however, is that localisation uncertainty can end up guiding the robot to unsafe areas and distort the model being learnt. In this paper, we address this problem and present a novel method that allows BO to consider localisation uncertainty by applying a Gaussian process model for uncertain inputs as a prior. We evaluate the proposed method in simulation and in experiments with a real robot navigating over rough terrain and compare it to standard BO methods which assume deterministic inputs.

sections.heading: 4.2 Bayesian optimisation under localisation uncertainty
sections.text: In order to extend BO to the context of uncertain inputs in robotics, we must first consider how input noise affects the BO process. In robotics, we can divide input noise into two categories: localization noise and execution noise. The first refers to noise that affects the robot's location estimation, usually due to imperfections in motion sensors and other types of sensors, such as GPS devices. The second type, execution noise, is the combined effect of anything that affects the execution of the robot path to a specific destination, such as localization noise, uncertain motion dynamics, etc.BO decides sequentially where the function being modeled, such as terrain roughness, is based on previous observations it has collected in previous steps. In the BO context, execution noise determines the actual location where an observation is performed, while localization noise estimation affects the estimation of the location.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we present experimental results obtained with our Bayesian Uncertain Input Optimization (UIBO) method in the presence of localization uncertainties. In all cases, we used the DUCB Acquisition Function [10] as a guide to the exploration process. We compare our method with two other approaches, the first being standard BO, which takes no uncertainties into account in the site estimates; the second is Bayesian Odor-Free Optimization (UBO) [15], which takes execution noise into account by means of the odorless transform [25], but assumes that the location estimate of the observation is correct.

sections.text: We conducted experiments with a physical robot outdoors to test the performance of the proposed BO approach with uncertain input compared to the standard BO with DUCB as in [22]. The purpose of this experiment is to highlight the differences in performance and behavior between the two BO approaches when faced with localization uncertainty in a real scenario.

The tests were carried out in an area where the terrain is covered with grass and where some parts of the robot are exposed to harder soil. The aim of the robot is to obtain a model of terrain roughness based on vibration measurements. As in simulations, the robot should be able to obtain a good model while avoiding rougher areas that cause high vibrations. In this scenario, excessive vibration can damage the robot or impair its ability to perceive the surroundings. Our robot was equipped with an IMU sensor placed on its chassis. sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: The proposed method offers a principled possibility to take this uncertainty into account in the inputs of a Gaussian process model used as a precursor to the BO algorithm. Execution noise is also taken into account by means of a query distribution in optimizing the BO capture function. It has been shown that the method outperforms other BO approaches in simulation and in an experiment with a physical robot. Therefore, the proposed method can be applied to problems where we are interested in mapping the transferability of a terrain but need to keep the robot safe in the midst of localization uncertainties. Some topics have not been addressed in this work, but are worthy of future research, one of which is the estimation of the execution noise that could be performed online by other statistical methods, for example by using the highest possible probability estimates for the parameters of a given distribution. Another topic is the extension of the DUCB method to include dynamic influencing factors that would consider both the way of exploring the environment as well as the implementation of many factors.
